head.title: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

hedline.hl1: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

abstract.p: Andrew Anmuth letter on Peter Applebome's July 2 column on how to react to black man playing loud and offensive rap music at gas station pump holds core issue is public civility, sense of etiquette or politeness expected of others (S)

block.p: Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.

The core issue in my opinion is the level of public civility, a sense of etiquette or politeness, that we should expect from others. Certainly, one would hope to have more of it in less crowded environments. But the truth is that in the Northeast one encounters rudeness on the road, in stores, in restaurants and other public places on far too many occasions.

The core issue in my opinion is the level of public civility, a sense of etiquette or politeness, that we should expect from others. Certainly, one would hope to have more of it in less crowded environments. But the truth is that in the Northeast one encounters rudeness on the road, in stores, in restaurants and other public places on far too many occasions.
The choice is to calmly ask someone to change what they are doing (maybe they are unaware?) or simply turn away, knowing it is hopefully a brief encounter.
On the other hand, we could buy a plane ticket to Europe and enjoy some Old World charm and a relaxing change of pace.
